pros: Young, vibrant, friendly workforce. Little politics, great selection of pantry drinks and food before they moved over to Block 71. Now it’s just all going downhill

Management love to criticize and challenge in the name of making ideas robust, everyone has grand ideas in all directions. Outcome is that working level is completely confused and doing a thousand things. The irony is management team is not affected by retrenchment. All the negative reviews before this is true, read it and make sure it’s fine with you before joining this company.

review_title: An almost incredible experience and dream job
pros: To clarify first, yes I was affected by the layoff, and I should had probably given my feedback whilst in the company but this is for jobseekers. Competitive payout for sales and they do constant review on this which is fantastic. Flexible dress code, Flexible hours( of course with you meeting KPI), Good benefits (AL, food voucher & transport allowance) and i truly believe the Founders are nice, trusting(maybe too much) and sincere even though I see some negative reviews on them here. Truthfully, the company was INCREDIBLE for any hungry sales associate when I first joined, they allowed us to acquire merchants from broad categories while recognising renewal sales from merchants we close, everyday I was excited to wake up looking forward to work ( how many can really say that in their job) to build carousell whilst helping merchants build their business growth with carousell and of course growing my paycheque! It was a dream job! With this system it was almost like i was running my own business and i look forward to close new merchants and renewing them showing them growth on their business. I wanted to stay here till retirement.
cons: Just too much went wrong so instead of typing them all out, i advise job seekers must be Extremely adaptable and okay with unfair KPI distribution and non thoroughly thought out major implementations… otherwise take a chance and cross your fingers for the higher end treatment due to negligence in target allocation and expectation. Still a 4 star cause i know founders are trying their best, just unfortunate they hired the wrong management. I truly feel sad.

review_title: Really great company to work for
job_title: Senior Software Engineer II in Singapore
pros:
This is the best company I have ever worked for. I joined the company around 2.5 year ago. 
I have a really great work-life balance while working here. I got married after a few months joining Carousell and I got a baby girl about a year ago. I was able to spent a lot of time with my family and my working hours has been very flexible. I would say I spent quite a lot of time during the day taking care and playing with my daughter and I work mostly when she is sleeping.
Really good managers. I think I was quite lucky to have a chance to work with very good managers. They gave me advices and opportunities to advance within the company. We have 1 on 1 regularly and generally we discuss about what I want to archive in my career and how to get there.
Excellent team and really smart people. Most people that I worked with at Carousell are very humble and open-mined, making it very easy for the team to discuss conflicting ideas and come up with good solutions.
The Carousell business is doing very well as well.
cons:
- No dental benefit
- The interviewing process can be quite long

pros:
- Culture is good
- People are nice
- Increase salaries when they see they are paying less than industry standards
cons:
I hope this review helps you decide whether to join the company or not 

- Leadership team is inconsistent (leaders quit quite often) and is of not top-notch quality except 1-2 folks. You can figure out the kind of questions they ask in meetings, which totally shows they have no experience in this domain
- Ask your HM during the interview, what is the companies strategy, what's the long-term plan. One day they want to become e-commerce for second-hand goods and another day they want to focus on 10 other items 
- Old employees/leaders play politics
- They increase salaries to retain employees (Attrition is always high here) but have no processes, structure in design, engineering, data, product 
- Company is 9 years old still extremely chaotic, with no processes, no structure, and also growth has been slow. Look at their peers which have grown significantly big 
- Leaders do mistakes and don't accept them which is horrible
- No focus on employee growth/career growth framework


Join the company if you - 

- Want to work in a startup that is still finding its overall strategy and is chaotic (okay with high attrition)
- Believe in their vision
- Talk to 4-5 ex-employees of your department and if you're convinced with their feedback then only join

Lot of good reviews on glassdoor surprize vs conversation I have with employees internally

pros:
Taught me how to survive a political warzone
Plenty of career opportunities for those who are good at the game
cons:
No work life balance
Insufficient benefits

review_title: One of the company to work with in SG
job_title: Senior Software Engineer II in Singapore

cons: Did not find any as of now

pros:
Colleagues are generally nice 
Better WLB than shopee and grab
cons:
Not really a con but here there’s no AWS or PB so how serious people take performance appraisals is sorely based on how much they still care to improve. 
Tech wise, they use GCP instead of AWS (like i said there’s no AWS :p) so it might take sometime to get used to for the folks in the AWS camp. 

There’s a lot of deprecated and poorly documented/hard to understand code because there’s no hard requirements on code standards. It makes people whom these code are handed over to miserable because they’re afraid to break things if they refactor. In general, very little best practices can been seen here, eg people commit large PRs expecting colleagues to review instead of doing a stacked PR, no formatting checks in auto test etc. It’s hard to push for a change in tech culture because the seniors are resistant. Then again, I guess all these are understandable because it’s not a tech company.

review_title: Strategy is a mess, directionless leadership
pros: You can have a lot of ownership depending on the team and role. Culture depends on the team. Compensation and benefits are ok.
cons:
Carousell has lost its way. They are trying to do too many things at the same time. Leadership is clueless on the right direction. There are competitors everywhere and it won't be long before they are under extreme pressure. Growth has slowed down and the product has suffered. Leadership keeps talking about using data but only when you have an idea, otherwise data doesn't matter when they want to do something.

Innovation has suffered as a result and you can see that in the product. Very slow vs. other tech companies.

Join if you are in the early stages of your career to learn some good processes and make some good friends. For senior people, stay away. Lot of people have left and they don't have any idea how to retain the others.

pros: Friendly people and nice onboarding package
cons: Nothing, really just joined so have no idea what gonna happens next

Great teammates who are willing to mentor you as well, and a manager that doesn't micro manage at all and is always looking to improve our working experience.
cons: Pay is alright compared to some top tier companies.

review_title: Please consider these points before joining
pros:
1. Most of the employees here came from worse working environments e.g. Media agencies, toxic local SMEs, Honestbee and hence believe that this grass is a lot greener. If you’ve been through terrible work environments, yes carousell will be (slightly) better. Is it the best place to work in Singapore? Definitely not. 

2. There is autonomy to make decisions that have immediate outcomes and visibility, and on some occasions the founders will be verbally grateful to you for them.

3. Most people on the ground here are really trying their best to do what they love and work hard. And yes, if you are looking to join the marketplace experience team, or the tech team - you are most likely to enjoy your experience there. Carousell understands that tech is competitive and will do their best to treat tech hires right, not so much for the other departments. 

4. In some departments, there’s a good culture of fun and team bonding. Carousell is intentional about spending time together and bonding, and there will be budget for this too.
cons:
1. The Carousell group acquired 4 companies over the years - OLX (Philippines), Mudah (Malaysia), Chotot (Vietnam) and OneKyat (Myanmar). There is a lot of mess and neglect in this process and the founders are struggling to understand how to manage them, most people here complain of being overworked, underpaid and under-supported way more than their Carousell counterparts.

2. Management - the Glassdoor reviews that you read here are true. Even though most of management came from affluent and long standing histories of experience, most of them just want to oppress their reports. They know nothing and want to be treated like royalty - you will be asked to book meeting rooms for them, teach them how to record on zoom/order food on foodpanda, buy things for them and much more. (To be fair, most of the things experienced are in the People team - high turnover rate a clue?) You will be shocked at how they can say words with no accountability and tact, despite their “experience”. The founders are much younger than most and clearly struggle to manage them - all these incidents mentioned were bought up to the founders and no action taken, resulting in employees resigning because they gave up hope. 

3. As much as they seem to look corporate and SME-like, most people here will admit that it’s still very much like a start up. Little to no processes, constant change in systems and poor communication downstream. 

4. There is a deep systemic resentment towards salary. The context is as a startup, most employees who have been there for years received start up pay. Only up till a year ago, the management decided to pay competitively to new hires and that’s when the bitterness and comparison arose. Imagine only getting half or less of the salary of your counterpart and doing the exact same work - as much as this is common, Carousell is not an MNC and it doesn’t come with any MNC benefits. 

5. Burnout culture: is real here. As much as the people experience team tries to sell “work life balance” and “Wellness Wednesdays”, they don’t actually live it out themselves. You will see the team reply to slack or send emails at 12am-1am, people are angry and uncooperative and being told they lack resilience when they are being pushed to breaking point at work. There is deep mistrust for managers as most of them are deemed inexperienced or incompetent. The people team try to mitigate but everyone can tell that they are struggling with their own manager, too. When asked, most of them are on the lookout for better opportunities and said that they will leave in a heartbeat if the opportunity presents itself.

review_title: Manager have no clue on how to run a company.
pros: No dress code and nice office
cons:
Culture: Management like to talk about how important they put people first. FYI the ‘people’ is the founders, management and ppl they like. Founders  like to appear and talk during townhall, but when it comes to execution it is zero.

Hiring the wrong people to do the wrong thing. 
- Do note that a lot of ppl they hire are ahbeng and ahlian that cant even speak properly. Most management are uncle aunty that have load of experience but have no clue how the tech and marketplace works. 

Company still not profitable.
- Imagine in the market for 10y and still losing money, this tells you how bad the company is doing. A lot of the verticals are still losing money until today. Since management are bunch or uncle and aunty, their idea of making money is to increase price of their subscription and ads for those verticals that are doing well.

Toxic Culture
- lots of politics in the company always regarding who the management likes and dislikes. For a company that is not profitable to have too many managers within a department. A lot of the associates they hire are ex-colleagues of the manages, and managers will prioritise these colleagues in terms of job assignment and promotion. 

Incompetent staff
- a lot of their managers are too incompetent. Asked their project manager a question and took him 2 weeks to answer me. He will organise a Q&A session with us, but its all questions since he cant answer us and can only note down those questions we asked and nvr answer us.

Founder is not taking this seriously.
They will come in office and chitchat with everyone like they are close friends. Talk like Steve Jobs during meeting and town halls but no have idea on execution and neither do they care.

pros: Managers operate on growth mindset. Learning is a two-way street.
cons: HR seem to think that qualification trumps experience every time. Should’ve been case by case but they don’t seem flexible enough. $500-800 difference pay from your colleague who has the exact same job scope as you is not very motivating.

review_title: Not a great place to work
pros: They have flexible hours to work and inter-team mobility is available after a while. Talented teammates.
cons:
- Culture: They talk pretty highly of their core values, but once it trickles down to following them, it's no where close. 

- Management: What they say is always right and they favor their own references and ex-colleagues when it comes down "trust". Personally, they don't treat HR folks as a business too so, HR opinion is the last opinion or better still "no opinion required" category. Highly bureaucratic/ political and very traditional in their approach and highly judgemental as leaders. 

- Attrition: a pretty high double figure attrition and a lot of people have left in HR /Tech/ product teams, clearly because they felt less heard or the leaders didn't work too hard to retain talent. Try avoiding 

- Interview process: is long, very long, very very long. They want to compete with FAANG company process but pay you peanuts in salary. They are always depending over budgets.

People team and TA team have maximum attrition this year, they say "i hear you" and ask you to move on. very insensitive even though they pretend to sound concerned and neglect you after sharing concerns.

Overall as an organisation, the co-founders pop up during townhalls to talk about company performance but very less invested in people and they go quiet on decisions for people. They may hear you out but they don't care to action out probably max assign your managers to deal with your issues. In that matter, none of the management really cares to hear about your concerns, it's too fake to be honest. So unless, you are a reference or you know some leaders well - you are bound to grow slowly in this space, highly biased in decisions and very likely to hear you out but not provide any solution or leave it to the managers to take biased decisions.

P.s. Carousell is more responsive on glassdoor than actually solving problems internally.

pros:

review_title: Lacks transparency, no focus on employee retention or career growth
pros: Flexible work environment, young and energetic team, collaborative, stocked pantry, free lunch on friday, pet-friendly, company has a good name for now and is growing quickly so looks good on the outside.
cons:
Founders have tunnel vision and are only focused on growth. Being a startup, it is understandable if the founders have no experience managing or leading a team, however it doesn't seem to be a focus for this company to learn how to do so properly even though founders seem to want to scale up the team extremely quickly.

After a while, employees will begin to realise that personal career growth is stagnating as well as founders have no system of appraisal or plan to help level up employee skills. This is especially a problem as founders have an extreme bias towards hiring many interns and fresh grads with no experience. 

Employee satisfaction is not a priority and there is a severe lack of transparency on how decisions are made, how compensation is awarded, what stock options are portioned out, future plans for company and so on. Employee opinions are also rarely taken into consideration in bigger decisions. Decision-making is top-down 80% of the time even if employees voice out concerns. The "grown-up" conversations and decisions are made by the founders only. Not as flat as it's made out to be.

review_title: One of the best work place in SG
pros:
-Missions & values are very clear
-People are passionate & dedicated to their work
-Nice office with warm vibes
-Lots of new and cool projects to work on
-Performance driven company
-Pantry always full of snacks and drinks
-Many events organised at our office. Alway something is happening here
-Every Friday, we have updates about the company -> transparency
cons:
OK i read some of the previous negative reviews and i think it's not fair and unjustified.
Carousell has surely lots to do to improve, not the perfect company yet but everyone is working really hard to build and make it a successful one.
Just like every startup at early stages, there are lots of uncertainties, challenges to overcome and difficult decisions to make, so yeah, Carousell is not a good place for the faint hearted

pros: fast paced, good culture and hiring many experienced seniors to shape and guide the future
cons: reorganisation happens frequently but expected of a growing company

review_title: Best place for people who want to see impact of their efforts at work
pros:
High impact work, from customer support to finance to engineering, others can see clearly how your work impacts the users & company. 

Team is relatively small and lots of information is shared, giving employees full understanding of the business. Great if you eventually want to build your own startup. 

People are incredibly diverse and interesting - I thought I'd be joining a very Singaporean startup but was glad to see how there's so many nationalities and people from all types of backgrounds. 

Product focused company that tries to solve things with good product , design and engineering. Strong appreciation for scalable engineering efforts and good design across the company.
cons:
Plenty of new priorities crop up as it does with startups, so employees need to be comfortable with changes and also be willing to find creative solutions to make things happen with limited resources. 

Hours can be long. So if spending some evenings and ocassional weekends working is not your thing, this isn't a good place for you.

pros:
Not stressful, 
Flexible management,
Code review,
Company believes employees
cons:
Legacy code, but improving
Salary not very high

pros: Some very talented individuals who are genuinely passionate about the business
cons:
- Laid back executive team, the founders work very very hard, the rest of them seems to be just there for the stock options, easy time and opportunity to travel around asia. Lack of discipline and focus
- Only people who gets promoted are the people in the executive team or their directs who are close with them! When communicating dismal results, in the same breath also announce promotion of executive member RESPONSIBLE for that result.
- Very political environment. If you agree with executive team, you are safe even if you do not perform. However, if you disagree or do not 'suck up' like the rest, you are in danger zone.
- Do not recognize talent and passion. Discriminatory.
- Change strategy every quarter, executive team seem to think that there is a contradiction between monetisation and user experience so keep jumping from one to the other.

review_title: I still love this place to bits, even if some parts aren't shiny
pros:
-Everyone understands their purpose and how the company functions as a whole
-No dress code
-People a fun to work with!
-You can learn a lot more than you'd expect, it just depends on what you want to take back at then end of the day
cons:
-Growing pains are slowly being addressed and some of us do get impatient, however it's good to note that everyone has good intentions, we just bite more than we can chew sometimes.
-Depending on your situation and your personality, you may or may not fit in well.
-Required to have much initiative and energy if you want to thrive.

pros: There is no dress code.
cons:
Management is very unprofessional. I've read the positive reviews here and I advise anyone reading to exercise caution. Founders will do anything to get people into the company but once you are in, you may (or may not, if they like you. favouritism is STRONG here) be taken for granted. 
Little is done to aid in personal growth for full-time employees. Additionally, you are expected to devote your life to improving the product. Nothing wrong with that, except that your feedback is irrelevant to them. And when you do give feedback, sometimes you will be met with the response along the lines of 'if others can do it why can't you?'. i.e. Do as you're told.
Also, management will never admit their shortcomings. You will never hear of a feature not living up to expectation or a management decision falling through the cracks. There is no transparency for the employees. 
Founders will also claim that Carousell has a great culture. Trust me, it isn't so great. The only culture I have experienced here is the bashing and ridiculing of competitor (and other) companies.

Rosy on the outside; rotten inside.

pros:
* relaxed dress attire


* nice colleagues 


* young team 


* well-stocked pantry


* free food on friday


* our own office 


* good company business idea
cons:
* founders are inexperienced and sometimes make decisions that upset employees, even after feedback 


* product focus lacks prioritisation on core experience of the app. Usually striving for quick fixes and deprioritizing the daily issues users face which requires significant engineering effort to fix


* think the founders are also not allocating resources properly. like marketplace quality is very important but lacks engineering support, same goes for customer experience and community


* transparency is also an issue. founders are always vague where compensation is concerned



* lack of professional growth for some departments. for instance, community support don't have a career trajectory. team is small and too busy fighting the high workload every day to think about career growth

pros:
There comes a point in your career when you’ll have to decide for what and whom you’re willing to work. Carousell unfortunately, despite its potential, is still far from reaching true innovation. And it’s certainly not because of the people. You’ll meet product managers, designers, engineers and marketers who want to contribute and have the talent to do so. Unfortunately, incompetent director lacks the vision and drains all creativity and brilliance from the “squad”. 

Some perks that you can expect working at Carousell: 
Snacks
Free Lunch provided on Fridays 
WFH optional once a week (dependent on team)
Nice people to work with
cons: Hiring incompetent director who lacks the understanding of what it means to strategise. Pushing features out quickly and hoping to gain adoption won’t work. Listen to your employees. If the majority of your team is asking you “what’s the strategy/roadmap?” and that strategy needs to be reworked, then try it. After all, if learning from failure is such a big part of company culture, what could be the harm?

pros: Friendly team. Free breakfast every morning from the managers
cons:
Promotes the incompentent, ignores the competent and fires the performant!
Most senior executive gets promoted and its like promoting a prime minister.
Creates non-existing roles just to fit favorite "personal" close friends
Senior team hands are not dirty, keep hiring more senior people and everything gets funneled down to the small number of worker bees
Management do not have ownership, when successful, there are alot of celebrations and back patting at the top. When we fail, its always because of certain fault of the junior people.
Sexist. Male management who only pay attention to each other and talks down to females
Celebrates failure
Set all the teams up for failure by not knowing how to set realistic goals and insist on impossible numbers
Founders have no idea how to run the business
Alot of senior people do not even use Carousell

review_title: Great working environment and many opportunities to learn
pros:
You get to own your own projects and really take charge and execute them.
Lots of freedom in exploring, and hence lots of learning opportunities as well. How much you want to learn is really up to you to go grab it. 
The team is pleasant and culture is accepting and fun - alot of my outside friends are envious of this! 
Fast paced growth as well, so if growth and new challenges to tackle and solve daily are your thing, this is the place to be!
cons: Things move fast here like in most startups - so be prepared to adapt quickly. If you are the kind that hates changes or don't like adapting to new things all the time, this may become stressful for you.

pros:
-Awesome co-workers who are passionate about the company and makes job bearable
-Free catered lunch every friday
cons:
-Very hacky and inefficient processes. I understand it is a start-up but some practices are questionable
-Unclear promotional criteria or even pay raise. Very hush hush nature, even managers not clear on how to recommend staff for promotion
-Useless employee feedback system. There is an anonymous system in place where you can voice out grievances but no actual follow up done 
-Unorganized upper management and leadership team

review_title: Only look good on the outside
pros:
Big investor names, Seqouia, 500 Startups.

Free food every friday

Friendly colleagues.

Pet friendly, but they can cause a disturbance at work
cons:
Employee's work here is undervalued. Founders believe in passion, and do not believe that employees need anything more than that. i.e. wanting you to think like them without offering competitive benefits. Company's funding is significant but not reinvested in existing employees compensation and skills to reward them for their work. The early employees who work the hardest are seldom appreciated.

Ideas and feedback from the employees are also not listened to. Founders appear to welcome feedback but the truth reveals itself over time.

Product has the ultimate priority. Staff's personal plans have to change because the company needs to grow. There's no respect for personal time.

review_title: A company united by its mission - unicorn in the making
pros:
Culture
1/ free to experiment and try out new things
2/ it's okay to make mistakes, just need an action plan to solve them
3/ carousell has a homely, family vibe
4/ transparent with data and direction

Office perks
1/ it's pet-friendly, we love to hang out with your dogs, cats, and hamsters
2/ quarter tech detox - company event outside of the office
3/ entertainment available: pool table, foosball, ping pong table, pandora arcade box, xbox kinect and BYOG
4/ casual dress code - like any other startups, as casual as you want
5/ you get to become a Carousell admin - mainly bragging rights
cons:
Talents
1/ started with a lot of fresh graduates; need more senior folks and middle management (Contrary to popular belief, this does not inhibit your learnings as a junior/newbie. experience comes from doing rather than listening)

review_title: A fun and great environment to work in
pros:
- humble bosses and team mates
- lots of flexibility given 
- work hours flexibility
- room for growth and personal improvement
- trust, ownership and autonomy given with job scope
- health benefits, free food from pantry & free lunch every friday 
- team retreats & outings 
- personal guidance and coaching from founders and leads 
- pet friendly 
- great company culture
- great team mates to work with 
- flat hierarchy
cons: none that I can think of

pros:
• There are plenty of opportunities here at Carousell. It really boils down to one's pro-activeness to reach out for these opportunities to grow.
• You also gain knowledge from experienced colleagues and an open sharing culture is emphasised.
• Founders and leadership team are also very approachable.
• The team is driven by mission to fill our users’ lives with meaningful experiences, and this helps to drive the focus of day to day work.
• Company is growing at an exciting pace with tremendous room for more and more growth.
• Personal experience working here is very positive.
cons: As with any fast growing company, a growing team means more communication overhead. Depends on how one wants to look at this, it all boils down to being deliberate about communication as more and more people come on board.

pros:
+ As a product person, you are put up with problems to solve and you work with people who challenge you and make you arrive at the right solution 
+ Everyone in the company cares about users. Good data/research findings help you win over the stakeholders fast. 
+ People are genuinely nice. Being an expat, it's a nice feeling to be in a place where people talk to you and help you out if you need anything
+ Executives are inspirational. Just manage to catch up with them every now and then.  There are days where I was feeling demotivated and having a simple chat with one of them helped me to feel positive about myself and what I'm doing for the company 
+ As a designer, you get to do extensive research visiting markets and talking to real users. The design team is humble and yet smart at what they do. They are ready to help you out if you are puzzled, but autonomy is encouraged for you to explore on your own. 
+ Bonus: VP of Product is super cool and he makes excellent cocktails 😄
cons:
- Carousell is not for everyone. It's a startup that has growing pains like other startups, but that's what makes it a good place for people to grow. The working life is not linear and there are some days you need to improvise on your role to get things done. 
- Manage your time better or end up stressing yourself out. The culture is very chill that there are no strict office hours and you can work from home. But if you are not careful, you will find yourself working on the weekends/weeknights because work is interesting. 
- When I was there, the leaves were low. As an expat, this was challenging because I had to plan vacations + visit home
- There will always be the things that could be better or could be improved. Don't think of them as cons/negative, but speak up and see it getting improved :)

pros:
- People are committed and motivated.
- Lunch every Friday.
- Transparent culture
- Friendly people
cons:
- Too much time spent in meetings. Not everything needs to be dragged for a couple of hours. Meetings could be made more streamlined and efficient.

- Not really a con as its understandable at this stage of the company but very few annual leaves.

review_title: This place will drain you eventually
pros:
Flexible working arrangements. Work from home, flexible working hours schemes which are subject to team manager
Casual dress code
Good people operations and IT ops team who ensure things are running smoothly. Many efforts to organize events for employee welfare and improve workplace functionality.
Family oriented with progressive values.
Talented peers.
cons:
Top-heavy structure. Management spends more time navigating power dynamics and politics. Very ineffective as no one wants or can step forward to make the ultimate decision since there are so many stakeholders. Junior levels are carrying the brunt of poor management decisions and cleaning up the mess. Management's questionable solution to this is to hire someone even more senior or create new upper management tiers. The circle repeats itself all the way up to C-suite. 

Incompetent middle managers. Managers don't just manage the job, they are supposed to manage the people doing the job. This differentiates them from the specialist route. But team building and mentorship capabilities sorely lacking. High attrition rate due to lack of career development and growth. 

Weak management. Has lofty goals but incompetent at strategy and foresight to plan ahead. 

Some founders and upper management do not respect the work you do and make ignorant demands even though it is out of their area of expertise.

Management is very good at fluffing to paint a rosy picture. Hides their head in the sand when it comes to acknowledging and addressing critical problems. When issues are brought to their attention, reactions are usually very defensive like take it or leave it or unless you have a solution don't raise it. Transparency and differing views are openly encouraged but don't fall for this. Check previous reviews who can vouch for this. There will be blowback. Many managers cannot handle feedback that doesn't sound good and will start subtly going against you in passive aggressive ways.

review_title: Undergoing Transition, but There's Good Potential
pros:
- Good fundamentals with a core user focus. Most employees genuinely want to do a good job and are not corporate-y. Unique culture, which makes one happy to go to work with like minded individuals.

- Strong potential to take extreme ownership of issues, and to drive them. People, including bosses are supportive. Just need to be entrepreneurial about it.

- Join if you want to learn fast, and by doing. There are a lot of opportunities to make a difference, and you can work across the teams, and there are no dogmatic rules to stop you.
cons:
- Managers can tend to be quite jumpy and reactive at times. Most have not worked with complex organisations or managed a large team before, so the resilience of the organisation and potential to develop employees has not caught up. 

- Ownership of initiatives can be lacking when it is unclear, which are missed opportunities. Some employees seem to lack a broader, company-level perspective and may not have the best set of capabilities to effect change. 

- This scale-up company that is undergoing a transition is not for everybody. Join if you want to make a difference. If you prefer a very structured environment and cannot roll with the punches, you will get frustrated.

pros:
Went through 4 layers of the interview process within 3days; 
1. Web F2F with HR 
2. Introduction to Team Manager (F2F) + Excel Test 
3. Interview with Team Manager & Team Members (F2F) 
4. Co-Founder Round (F2F)

I was offered the position 5 hours after the Co-founder round. 

Culture vibes are awesome, people are very nice and steer more to the positive side. Things move very fast and the ability to stay nimble is very much appreciated. Be open-minded and you will appreciate the work environment. Its also a flat hierarchy and everyone's opinion is encouraged.
cons: Transparency of expectations between team manager & teammates.

review_title: Was one of the best Culture in Singapore. Somehow turned upside down.
pros:
Talented colleagues but many left.
Young employees, fun to play with.
Flexible working time.
Small scrum team, moves fast and easily senses impact in your work.
Inspiring CEO
cons:
No clear performance review. Some people staying with the same title same job same pay for a long period of time.
Engineers are not recognized for their works. Promotion keeps going to managers and those who are close with managers. 
Value managing skills over technical.  
Try to push engineers for a lot of new features. Engineers are frequently OT but are not treated fair.

pros: Free food & drinks on Friday
cons: Apparently head of sales typically have no ideas of running the show. When was told to brainstorm ideas to achieve targets, all they can say is not workable. They themselves have no knowledge at all to run the business. Distribution of sales accounts wasn't fair at all. Gossips are at all time high. Other departments have politics among themselves & play hierarchy. That is why turnover rate is super high. Hence overall 2019 performance was doing badly.

pros:
You can drive a big impact for users. There's a big difference when you work in a company this size, versus working in companies with thousands or even hundreds of thousands of people.

People are working to make things better across the company - from Tech to Monetisation and many other teams. We are improving our practices and documentation etc. There are also new leaders to help guide us in the right direction. But I don't think we should be expecting big changes overnight. Many changes will take time because there are long-standing issues to solve. But at least we are moving in the right direction.

We work in a casual environment that offers a lot of flexibility. Not as many restrictions as compared to other companies. Most managers give people the freedom to lead and drive projects. 

Most people you will meet here are young, energetic and passionate about their work. This energy is needed to keep up with such a fast paced environment. But this can be a double edged sword, as some of them do not have the maturity that comes with experience and also age.

There are other perks like free lunch on Fridays, well stocked pantry etc. Small stuff but makes the experience better.
cons:
After reading some of the past reviews, you can guess how challenging our environment is. Some of the reviews written before are kind of unreasonable though. It feels like an overgeneralisation and exaggeration of many issues. Nonetheless I agree with some of the points that were brought up, including having better direction and more open communications. 

I feel that the no 1 issue is communications. Everyone will benefit if we can all be better communicators, from the top all the way to the bottom. And communications is a 2 way street. Management should be more transparent and share more with us, but we on the receiving end should also be receptive to new info and changes.

review_title: A great place to work in
pros:
- fun and relaxed environment with young and talented colleagues
- nurturing and collaborative 
- opportunities to learn from one and another and across various functions
- dog-friendly
- focus on building a quality product
cons: - you lose track of time when you are working at Carousell

pros: fun and young team, great company culture, experimental approach and mindset, a lot of autonomy! founders genuinely care for staff and take effort in knowing everyone of them. collaborative culture and flat hierarchy :) exciting possibilities ahead.
cons: not many i can think of

review_title: Nice at one glance, culture isn't great
pros: "Good work environment" depends on your team. Flexible hours, can work from home. Pet-friendly. Pantry with snacks.
cons:
Favouritism and biases in the office! Previously didn't feel like there was politics going on, but now there is. 

Culture feels shallow -- some free food, eat together sometimes, people seem to be happy in the surface. But teams are not collaborative, and there's a lot of communication problems. 

Tries to do everything at the same time; not much focus.

review_title: Overall, a great company to work for!
pros:
- People here are friendly, helpful and open to sharing
- Able to learn and gain knowledge in a wide variety of things
- Love how we are working towards a meaningful goal
cons: - Improvements are sometimes slow but guess we are slowly improving our processes/standard procedures/communication process

pros: colleagues are very friendly, helpful and caring! humblest, nicest co-founders ever. able to learn lots as everyone is willing to share their knowledge.
cons: company (system, job positions etc) was a bit messy at first but it's normal cus it's a startup. things are a lot better now

review_title: 2 months review - great place to work
job_title: Head of Data Science in Singapore
pros:
1. Mission driven - one of the company's core values is "Mission first" and I see how that drives lot of decisions, esp. when there are cross-group conflicts.
2. People & Culture - very talented and humble + collaborative bunch of folks. Healthy respect for each other and a fun work environment.
3. Opportunity for Impact - Large volumes of data, good user base, lots of great opportunities to do meaningful work.
cons: Trying to do many things at the same time. Can be more focused on a few big wins first.

pros: It is a very young and dynamic company culture with a great mission. People truly believe in the mission here. The solve great challenges for 7 markets around Asia - bug growth potential. The hiring process took 2 weeks with an HR assessment, interview with the product directors, solving a product challenge (case), presentation of the case and a final interview with the CEOs. However, this whole process only takes around 2 weeks.
cons: The benefits are still limited they offer for expats, but they are planning to improve on it soon.

review_title: The company is good, but has some unnecessary "politics"
pros: The benefit is good, the culture is also cool and of course it also depends on which team ur working in.
cons: There are some people in there trying to play "politics" but the upside is if you don't mess with them, ur totally ok. There are also some people so aggressive, always bother the people around to try to show their affects.

review_title: Nice place but can be better
pros:
Nice and smart co-workers
Great culture
cons:
Unnecessary politics
No personal growth (joining as a junior means you will most probably be stuck at the bottom for good)
No clear company direction
Bad at hiring 
No balls to take immediate action to fix the mistakes
Everyone just wanna be a good cop and no one wants to point out the mistakes

p.s.
Perfect for people who want to be a manager, soft (people) skills are more valued than hard skills and results in Carousell

pros:
- free food on friday
- many good engineers, can learn a lot
- non formal environment
- can work from home a lot
- good money
cons:
- lack of direction, management look clueless
- like to setup unrealistic expectation, somehow 'discourage' reaching green OKR (if you meet expectation they will say you dont set goal high enough)
- high turnover rate
- execs have no idea of tech and engineering, leading to lots of dubious tech decisions that make engineers suffer
- no meritocracy, lots of nepotism
- lack of transparency, many decisions made at sudden without consulting tech/product owner
- no growth opportunity, performance review mainly formality

pros:
- Very fast & efficient recruiting process
- Quick turnaround time on queries
- Quick decision making on next rounds & overall offer
- Very considerate in terms of adjusting for personal issues during transition from old employer/location to Carousell location / office
- Day 1 of joining very efficient and well structured (all assess / tools / accesses / laptop setup etc ready and a quick brief onboarding half day structure)
cons: - None that I can think of so far

review_title: Management needs to get serious about dealing with real issues / Limited growth for full-time staff
pros:
• Flexibility to work from home

• Pet-friendly

• No dress code so you can show up in t-shirt and shorts, and no one cares

• Pantry is usually well-stocked with snacks and soft drinks
cons:
• Management is disorganised - Always taking on more than they can handle and/or doing things at their whim and fancy, and then they end up not doing it well, causing the rest of the team to clean up and bear the consequences.

• Decisions are top-down most of the time and the organisation is not as flat as what the management makes it out to be.

• Interns get more opportunities to learn and grow, whereas full-time employees are constantly denied such opportunities, even if they propose useful ideas and volunteer to practice skills they've acquired from prior work experience. Interns' also seem to be given more power over full-time staff and are allowed to run amok, doing and saying whatever they want.

• Lack of proper policies in place to govern professional conduct, and that's not ideal given how rapidly the company is growing.

• Management is often not transparent about plans for the company, and when asked, they give vague answers and try to side step those questions. Full-time employees often want to help but are deliberately excluded and denied, despite their best interests for the company.

• Management seems to be resistant and unadaptable to changes and challenges, which is contrary to the image that people see from the outside. It does really look better from the outside than from the inside.

• Management always sit on the fence when decisions are required, big or small, and things take a lot longer to get done as a result. Most of the time, if they don't immediately agree, it is because something was not what they liked/wanted to hear, and providing good reasons to back something up is never enough. 

• Management always chooses to hear the good things and ignore the bad. This is a problem because serious issues have arisen as a result of their negligence and failure to commit to solving urgent issues that will directly affect the performance of all functions, as well as the overall reputation of the company.

• Management talks about growth A LOT but don't seem to have a sound plan for execution and success. A lot of things seem haphazard and wilful.

• There is a lack of accountability as the management seems to have gotten a bit complacent... Some times, a lot of talk to make things sound good but no follow up action to fulfil it.

• The team is VERY young and most are inexperienced, so it takes some level of patience to deal with it appropriately. One has to learn how to manage one's own expectations on how long certain supposedly simple things take to get done, and to what levels of standard. Quality of work is not a strong suit around here.

pros: In the last 6 months, a lot have been changing and you wouldn't think that we're still the same company we were 6 months ago. I see a lot of effort from the company leaders to make positive changes and trying to listen to what we want.
cons: Because of how fast the company is growing, it almost feels like the changes take a relatively longer time to really impact on people on the ground.

review_title: The most draining 2 years in my entire working life
pros:
- No dress code
- Semi flexible working hours
- Free buffet spread menu every Friday 
- Inspiring leaders
cons:
- Incompetent team leader

- Serious lack of transparency 

- High turnover rate

- No room for career progression 

- Lack of appreciation for staff who actually do the work and go beyond 

- Hierarchy system: to climb up the ladder, you’re going to have to agree with everything they say and support their decisions even if it does not make sense. Also, be quick to turn a blind eye whenever negative repercussions resulting from awful decisions made by the management team arise

- Unless you’re "up there", be prepared to take every hit and fall that comes your way when your manager leads the team down a dead end street, while the higher-ups will get all the credit and glory IF and when things (surprisingly) go right

- Differing views and opinions are openly and actively encouraged, but if you want to survive here you’d better keep your thoughts to yourself. 100% of the time, managers don’t really want to hear anything other than what they already think they know, so don’t be fooled. 

- Be prepared for important decisions to be made by managers without any prior discussion or consideration for the people who will be negatively affected. When this is highlighted, which it has many times before, the response from them will be something along the lines of "take it or leave it”

- HR team is all talk and no action, even when multiple employees within the same team highlight similar issues and pain points 

- Founders are probably not as clueless as they pretend to be about these issues, not when word and gossip spreads at lightning speed and issues within individual teams are hot topics between other teams

pros:
- (not exactly a pro) culture was good a few years ago, not anymore as the company  is in a stage of uncertainty and "transitioning" to become more corporate
- people here are generally nice and friendly
- flexible working arrangements
cons:
- management can't settle on ONE CLEAR direction and can change strategy at the very last minute and thinks it's acceptable in the name of a "start up" that needs to "move fast"

- claims they are user-centric, but nothing done in the company is user centric in ANY way

- when the company started to hire more experienced people, the culture started to change to become more corporate but yet strategy is still all over the place

- very complicated organisational structure that makes no sense and is extremely hard to navigate

- nothing is compulsory here. so many thousand problems we have to solve, but can't even find an appropriate project owner because of the complicated organisational structure. if there's no owner, it'll never get solved and that's how Carousell is still stagnant and can't solve it's core user problems while trying to make money out of users

- HR policies for promotions are extremely unjust. Peers with same level of experiences that got promoted before the new "review system" are safe, happy and satisfied at work; and others that are working extremely hard, frequently having to OT, contributing much more to the company and with the same level of experience don't get promoted because of "HR policies" in the name of making things more "structured". 

This company doesn't value loyalty, your contributions and the value you bring. Promotion criteria are ambiguous and not made known to employees - they tried to map a competency chart, of which if you reach the next level you might not even be promoted because of other unknown HR policies that are not communicated at any point and they expect you to accept the fact that you are subjected to them anyway.

Makes you feel cornered with no choice but to either accept the unfair policies or to leave.

review_title: Great Experience in Multi Cultural Company
pros:
1. Multi Culturalism, you get to know people from many countries. Literally more than half are foreigners with interesting stories
2. Fast paced - fast learning
3. Inspiring leaders and company-mission
cons:
1. Documentation is scrambled around
2. Your ear needs to be good with many accents
3. Pace can really be intimidating, not recommended if you are blur

pros: Cant think of anything except abit later than usual start work timing, free lunch every friday
cons: Lol! Whole top management is too proud to even talk to employees, looking down on us. Their noses are too high up in the air.  Now its the worst company ever to be in. Place is overcrowded with foreigners. Salaries are being deducted by half during 2nd year to buy options, locking employees' money away and boosting their own revenue in a way!! What a total joke! You dont have a choice! Join at your own risk. You will definitely suffer!

review_title: Energetic, open and bottom up environment
pros: a set of fast learning talents, bottom up culture, strong product mindset across the company.
cons:
too many things want to achieve at the same time, resulting in lost of focus. conflicting features across teams.

C level always avoid taking final decision/resolving conflict when teams consensus can't be made, lead to frustration.

pros:
- having 4 stage of interview process (They are serious in getting who they want to hire)
 - nice co workers 
 - Free flow drinks and food at pantry
cons: - room for improvement in the onboarding process

pros: Good culture and collaboration, people are young and fast learning. Good life work balance. Clear social value seen from what the company is doing
cons: A bit lack of ambition. Previously none meaningful perf review was hold, and now it’s getting better. Uniqueness is lowering down.

pros: Its hyped up by the tech scene
cons:
Management has no idea what they are doing
Recruiters suck and hire their friends and family 
People here are extremely arrogant and if you say something back like a better idea or some improvement metrics, they will find ways to take you out

pros: Engineering team is great and people are talented
cons: Nothing specific.  Just the office space is getting small to accommodate so many people, but they are trying to fox that too

pros: Great team! Very energetic and passionate!
cons: Not enough time to work with them more

pros:
- Awesome colleagues
- Good engineering practices
- Focus on making the product better
cons: - We have company lunch on Friday, but the lunch is just ok, I think

pros:
- Smart colleagues
- Free food on Fridays
cons:
- Questionable management
- Losing quite a few talented engineers

pros: The people there are friendly and close to one another.
cons: It is a very fast paced company. So be prepared for it.

pros: The pantry is well  stocked and the enviroment is good to work
cons: It gets noisy at times

pros:
Young engineers
Full of joy in the office

Not well organized
Dont see any innovation

review_title: A great place to work at.
pros: Great colleagues. Love the environment
cons: Nothing really much in particular

pros: get to know all the latest tech info
cons: must be able to be multitask in a fast pace

pros: Great work life balance. Smart people and friendly senior management.
cons: Below-industry pay, some red tape

pros: Love the people in this company.

job_title: IT Manager in Woodlands New Town,
pros: Nices Company in the world
cons: Goods in the singapore Companies

pros: Very gd place 2 b
cons: Benefits not great can b better

pros: friendly colleagues and culture. work-life balance.
cons: too many products, which means hard to maintain and sell, esp vertical. Media and merchant sides are good, but need to think how to strengthen these categories and keep the momentum and resolve the gaps, i.e. payment, logistics, trust issue.

pros: colleagues are talented, manager are really thoughtful and helpful.
cons: Loading in some teams are pretty high, I often have to work over time to make things done

pros: People are friendly. Working hour is flexible. Enable remote work.
cons: A little buzy. Business model is not clear. Office is not that comfortable.

review_title: Tech/Data teams dominated by a certain nationality
pros: Pros: - laidback culture - fully remote working style - decent base salary - generally nice teammates at rank and file level
cons: Cons: - Tech/Data leaders mostly foreigners, particularly of a certain nationality (some are even based in their home countries) - no cash bonus - no profitability in sight - likely to raise a down round at current growth trajectory

review_title: Barriers to Entry into the HK Market are Massive
pros: They have nice modern offices in a good location
cons: It's an impossible task trying to break into a market with a number of competitors that have been established for nearly two decades.

pros: -Wonderful work culture -No pressure. -Support from Manager and site lead -Company understands work-life balance and respect that. - You get to work with top thought leaders - smart, collaborative, and willing to share. - Flexible working hours and adaptive work environment.
cons: Haven't come across any as of yet.

pros:
Flexible
good pay
good benefits
good learning opportunities

review_title: Stress free work environment and good compensation!
pros: Flexible and stress free work environment. Competitive compensation. Lots of opportunities for learning and improvement.
cons: SDLC could be improved as far release cycle goes

review_title: Title inflation, stressful to meet unrealistic target
job_title: Business Development Manager in Quarry Bay
pros: Large, comfortable and convenient office
cons:
- Poor branding and marketing strategy leading to poor demand driving to Property, Autos and Services sectors
- Unrealistic target and termination will be carried out for employees not meeting targets, making low morale
- Less resources and support from management level, implementing business plans for potential merchants by ourselves
- Require cold calls and you will expect to be rejected a thousand times a day

review_title: Flexible time, great culture, lots of opportunities to grow
pros:
listening to their people
humble and down to earth leadership (local and regional)
great culture
co-founders are very humble, hands-on and inspiring
no late night /after hours meetings
very trusting of the employees/colleagues
cons: cascade of processes should be communicated properly to the team before implementation

review_title: Carousell is a high growth, fast paced environment and the company's culture is designed for problem solvers
pros:
:: Mission-first company --- aiming to inspire every person in the World to start selling & buying to make more possible for one another
:: Company culture is designed for problem solvers; if you can solve major blockers / issues, you'll also gained tons of learnings & growth as a result.
:: When it comes to solving meaningful problems, many of us also take extreme ownership and tend to over-communicate to ensure alignment. Some people may be surprised at first... but you'll eventually realize it's a norm at Carousell.
:: Team members here will speak up when in doubt or call out things if it doesn't seem right. And we even do it during comms / townhall sessions with CXO level. I love the fact that many here feel safe for speaking up and asking relevant questions even to senior management. Kudos to the People's Team to organize such forums.
cons:
:: Ambitious goals, need to stretch ourselves to make magic happen together with the squad / working team
:: The tech environment and our marketplace is constantly evolving... so you'll have to keep up with the pace and be relentlessly resourceful to get things done

review_title: So glad to be a part of the Carousell team!

The work culture is great and it has truly been an amazing journey so far!

review_title: Talented colleagues, but lacks the room for growth
pros:
- Talented colleagues that can inspire you and gain your professional skills.
- You won't feel bored because there are lots of challenge that are awaiting for people to work on and gain experience from them.
cons:
- Questionable hiring process that during the great expansion of 2017 some incompetent persons with bad ethics of profession and improper behaviour were hired even they lack the required skills and personalities for the positions.
- Questionable management that some people received endorsements from managers because they made decisions and contributed their work that can give them perfect look experience in their own CV but bringing negative impact to the revenue and reputation of the company, hence extra cares are needed from other colleagues.
- Lack of promotions and recognitions to colleagues who actually do the work above and beyond by making their own hands dirty. They stuck to the same level, pay, position, and team for years.
- Over emphasising the importance of managerial skills that people got promoted even they lack the required professional skills for the previous position. And no room for career growth to colleagues who mainly focus on professional skills.
- Keep losing talented colleagues.
- The pay and benefit are not good enough considering the unusual work load that brought by incompetent colleagues. Also not competitive when compares to the role with a similar requirements and responsibilities in other companies.
- The time off in lieu is out of proportion (less) to the time of working overtime.

pros:
1. flexible working hours
2. able to work from home
3. free food during employee gathering on Friday
4. casual startup atmosphere
5. they got new improved health benefits
cons:
1. instability, KPI changed every now and then
2. some incompetent and micromanaging managers who can't handle criticism
3.  lack of transparency regarding decision making in executive level
4. literally no room for growth, there is no clear criteria for a promotion and most employees  will be stuck in the same entry level position
5. no leadership development
6. someone mentioned that Carousell has a useless employee feedback system: I can confirm this. employers rarely followed up  the issues voiced out by employees

review_title: Very fast phase, amazing work culture!
pros:
Super fast phase
You are allowed to do everything from A to Z
Your ideas are valued
Respectable founders
Down to earth folks and colleagues
Like minded humans
Hustlers for the win
Alot of help from team mates
Good team work
Strong founders and investor support
Scrappy style of events with a twist
Every milestone is celebrated
Your Birthday is valued!
Family Friday luncheon and an in house speaker with a fun topic!
cons:
Long hours and weekend but it's how you plan your time
Difficult decisions but it's how you plan the strategies

Might feel alienated if not in a team of 2 or more people-IC roles beware
